intro: Nigella arvensis var. microcarpa, commonly known as the lesser cumin or Persian cumin, is a flowering plant native to Central Asia and parts of Europe. It is a member of the Ranunculaceae family and produces small, delicate yellow flowers that bloom in early summer. The plant typically grows to a height of 20–50 cm and has finely divided, fern-like leaves. Its seeds, which are small and black, are used in traditional medicine and as a spice in some cuisines. The plant thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in disturbed habitats such as fields and roadsides.
